texts.definition: Gameplay where players take on the goals and behaviors of fictional agents.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay where players take on the goals and behaviors of fictional agents.</style>

Games require players to adopt goals but some games make players adopt the role of fictive people and the roles they have goals. This can require the players not only to strive for those goals but to behave as agents which have those goals, including having the emotional attachment to them that the agents would have having to plan how to strive for those goals and choose between them.

For a detailed analysis of early roleplaying games, see Peterson 2012 and for early roleplaying culture see Fine 2002. Mackay 2001 looks more generally on Tabletop Roleplaying Games and Cover 2010 explores how they help create narratives. Appelcline 2011 and Tresca 2011 provide two different perspectives on the evolution of these games. In Dungeons & Desktops, Barton does the same for Computer Roleplaying Games. For Live Action Roleplaying Games, see Stark 2012 for an overview of the American version and Montola & Stenros 2010 for the Nordic version.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Many of the best known <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">tabletop roleplaying game</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Basic%20Roleplaying">Basic Roleplaying</link></style>, are actually game systems that can use different game worlds. These game worlds can be totally player-created, but there are also commercial game worlds available. Other games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ars%20Magica">Ars Magica</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallen%20Reich">Fallen Reich</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paranoia">Paranoia</link></style>,  and the various games in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Storytelling%20System">Storytelling System</link></style>, are instead created to specifically support on particular game world. The gameplay is based on the group of players that roleplay members of a party going adventuring in sometimes exquisitely detailed fantasy settings with elaborate plot structures. In these games, most often only one of the players is the Game Master (''Dungeon Master'' for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> but Game Master is the more generic term) who acts as the game facilitator presenting and resolving the imaginary situations to the players. The gameplay is usually almost wholly based on verbal communication between the players and the Game Master. Rules, resolution tables, and dice are used to resolve the conflict situations, which usually involve combat between players and monsters.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> replaced the need for game masters by having code. This let players engage in <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> alone, e.g. in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style>. When computers became networked, this gave rise first to ''Multiuser Dungeons'' such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> (and re-introduced human <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>), and later <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Entropia%20Universe">Entropia Universe</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disney's%20Toontown%20Online">Disney's Toontown Online</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20Online">Ultima Online</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sleep%20is%20Death">Sleep is Death</link></style> is noteworthy in this context since it is a computer-based roleplaying game intended for one game master and one single player, as is the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> since it lets one player roleplay many characters or ''Sims''.

In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games (LARPs)</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/1942%20%E2%80%93%20Noen%20%C3%A5%20stole%20p%C3%A5">1942 – Noen å stole på</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Prosopopeia">Prosopopeia</link></style>, players act out their characters in real life. The real world is used as the basis for the setting of the game although it may be modified by for example constructing buildings, and players often put many hours into make the appropriate props and equipment as good as possible. LARPs, of course depending on the play style, are usually more oriented on acting out the roles of the characters than <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">tabletop roleplaying games</link></style>, and some play styles are closer to improvisational theater than playing games.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Gamebooks">Gamebooks</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Warlock%20of%20Firetop%20Mountain">The Warlock of Firetop Mountain</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lone%20Wolf%20series">Lone Wolf series</link></style> are "single-reader" <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> games.

Some games introduce <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> in the form that players need to pretend they are another form of players than they are. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> does this through having some players as traitors that try to sabotage the efforts of the other players, while in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style> spies in disguise need to move as part of the other team in order to avoid detection. The latter example forces the players to enact a type of roleplaying using only movement and facing (since they cannot shoot or talk to members in the enemy team).

For more examples, see the categories <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is based on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> between players and game components that could be <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in their own right (at least on a diegetic level), so a primary need for the pattern is to create such suitable game components. This is typically <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (making them <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>) since they can have goals and intentions associated with them which players can adopt, but arguably <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> such as countries in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> or civilizations in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> can work.

The <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> needs goals and intentions, and some are more common that others since they inherently have more complexity and thereby let players have more <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> in how to perform them (having no <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> would make the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> stop being agents). <style="Link"><link="secret-goals">Secret Goals</link></style> provide an easy was to require multiple levels of <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>, first as having the goals that the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> have and then trying to hide that one has these goals. <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> is a common solution and can exist as <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> within the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> or within groups of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>. A special case of <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> for <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is that players can have it between him- or herself and the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> played. <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agenda</link></style> can be said to do <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>, but it is unlikely that players will differentiate between the <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Player</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> so this is primarily a structural observation.

Another solution, intended to make <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> easier for players, is to let players choose the goals and intentions for the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> of them. This can be extended to choosing their appearance as well (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> easily does this while later instances of computer-based games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> have numerous options), up to the level of support <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style> can also be used to provide players with broad set of rules regarding how their players should behave; this can guide players in selecting more specific goals and intentions.

<style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is easily and effectively done by saying or doing what one's <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> is doing. Quite often it is seen as a goal by both designers, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, and players that those playing should try and use <style="Link"><link="diegetic-communication">Diegetic Communication</link></style> as often as possible as a low level of <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>. However, this means that <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can encourage players to engage in more <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style>, but when a game's design explicitly requires the latter it in reality requires <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>.

Many games focusing on <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> often wish to provide a large amount of <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> for players on how to portray the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> they are <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sandbox%20Gameplay">Sandbox Gameplay</link></style> can provide players with this freedom while <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can not only roleplay <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> but can also improvise ways of allows players to do what they want. However, too much freedom can also be a problem, e.g. in regards to maintaining <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> or unfolding a certain <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Predetermined%20Story%20Structure">Predetermined Story Structure</link></style>, and in these cases <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> may be necessary - but too much control may make <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> limited, impossible, or reduced to pure <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> without any possibility for players to improvise.

Games with <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> typically require some kind of <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> to support the environment and possible <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>. Using human <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> allow for improvisation and <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> can support the large numbers of players needed simultaneously to create <style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style>.

An alternative way of achieving <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> in games is to introduce <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>. This since a player is <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> when pretending to have other intentions than he or she in fact has, as for example playing a ''Cylon'' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> requires. By combining <style="Link"><link="anonymous-actions">Anonymous Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> and the risk of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, a <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> can occur without being detected if the betraying player succeeds in <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>. <style="Link"><link="sanctioned-cheating">Sanctioned Cheating</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> works much like <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> in relation to <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> expect dealing with pretending not to be doing certain actions.

The same effect can be achieved through having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Infiltrate">Infiltrate</link></style> goals (and can be said to work for <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>), as for example through the spy class in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20Classic">Team Fortress Classic</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="secret-goals">Secret Goals</link></style> in any <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Game</link></style> can serve a similar purpose but does not have to be as easily noticeable by other since players are not forced to pretend to have any specific goals.

A special case of <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> exists when players pretend to be other players than they themselves are. This may not be to impersonate other, but rather to be able to have a <style="Link"><link="possibility-anonymity">Possibility of Anonymity</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

Games that are to support <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> need at least implicit <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> since the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> that are to be roleplayed need an environment to offer possibilities and challenges. The use of <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> (as done for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> but also most <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>) can change how <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is done - for example having to consider long-term effects of actions - but it player actions can change the <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> then <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> also effect it in return, up to becoming <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style> can help players in experiencing the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, are through this help them with <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>.

As part of providing sufficiently detailed <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, games support <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> often need to provide players not only with the possibility to interact with other players but also to interact with diegetic entities such as <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>. For the <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> to become a interactive exchange and have flexibility, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> may need to roleplay the <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> rather than having them be their own <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>.

Given that players quite easily may break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> or even <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> when not <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> properly, e.g. by engaging in <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Enforced%20Actions">Player Enforced Actions</link></style> may be worth considering if these are deemed important.

<style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style> directly affects how <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is done, and since it is a form of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style>, there are reasons to avoid it if striving to uphold <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

While <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> makes <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style> as well as vocal <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> possible, enforced <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> can compartmentalize <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/In%20Character%20Conversations">In</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> to help support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="emotes">Emotes</link></style> can help players express the emotions of their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and thereby roleplay.

Players often need to enact what <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do and be able to relate to these <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> way of thinking when roleplaying. <style="Link"><link="workshopping">Workshopping</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="warming-up-roleplay-exercises">Warming-Up Roleplay Exercises</link></style> are techniques that can be applied to tabletop and live action games with <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> to help players with these tasks as well as help develop the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and their relationships to other <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> if necessary.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> games naturally tend to have strong <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> to motivate the goals and desires of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, as well as increasing the possibilities for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style>. However, they may need to be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style> if they are to function together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> in the power of players but <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style> shows another way this can be done.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is a type of performance and can through this create <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style> in games. <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> typically leads to <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> in various forms but not always - while <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> can consist of moving <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Miniatures">Miniatures</link></style> on  maps and speaking as one's <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> would, it can also just consist of stating what actions one is doing without any <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> whatsoever. When it does happen though, this <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> can help support <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and show <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style> to what happens in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. Regardless, adopting the goals of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> can lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style>, and choosing how to reach their goals and enact their interactions is a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>. While controlling <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can in itself be enough for players to engage in <style="Link"><link="perspective-taking">Perspective Taking</link></style> of those <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> views upon things, <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> makes this more likely since the <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> puts a stronger foci upon taking into account more diegetic aspects - not necessarily connected to game mechanics - relating to the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.

As the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that are played are likely to have <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, players engaged in <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> are also likely to take on these <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style> for how their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> behave. All <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> games happen in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> since the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> need an environment, but the <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can define the smaller (and sometimes bigger) details of these <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and with sufficient <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> they can become <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> can be achieved through <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> as soon as players feel that they managed to play according to the wants and personality of their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (which can be regardless of if they as people share these things or if the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> succeed in what they attempt to do). <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can require <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> on two levels: that of enacting the <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> of someone and that of supporting others <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> and not dominating <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style>.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can lead to the closure of the goals and intentions of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, it can also lead to <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> when players have <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that they roleplay, and some of the actions players chose are likely to be <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> is most common in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, and there creates a particular form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, it is not necessary and can therefore <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> can be seen as a way to modulate <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>. This <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> can give rise to quite a number of different types of activities, e.g. <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style> during <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, and that they have additional limitations, e.g. that <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> in itself does not specifically motivate <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, but when modified explicitly by "social" structures such as <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> or implicitly by the setting through a wish to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, it can.

Examples of situations where <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can occur even when no other player are present, and thereby modulate <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, include when making a country behave as it did historically while playing one of the games in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> or when playing a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style> as one decided it should behave during its creation. These are further examples of how <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can support <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>.

When done in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> are often structured so that the players belongs to <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> and this quite naturally demands <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>. However, they require <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> on another level - that of upholding <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style> and the possibility of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style>. One common issue regarding this <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, and which can require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, is that <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> may give rise to both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/In%20Character%20Conversations">In Character Conversations</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> and that different players may have different opinions on their appropriateness and how much it disturbs <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> games with human <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> typically contain large amounts of <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, being not only what <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can use to drive the game forward but also being how players can describe their actions and how <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Effect%20Descriptions">Effect Descriptions</link></style> of those actions. However, telling what specific <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do is <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> as long as they act according to their personality and context, so <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can together give rise to <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style>. Conversely, <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> through <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> gives rise to <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>.

In game with <style="Link"><link="anonymous-actions">Anonymous Actions</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> can be needed on the level of roleplaying oneself as a player to win. That is, <style="Link"><link="anonymous-actions">Anonymous Actions</link></style> can make <style="CurrentLink">Roleplaying</style> a requirement for <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>.
